sp.p: She must so, which she may easily do, talking much, for women wants not words, neither are we sparing of them; but captain, I must entreat your company, for you are acquainted with the country, and hath the experience of the humours and natures of that people, and having been a soldier and a traveller, will not be to seek in the ways of our journey.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: I shall wait upon you, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady wagtail.
sp.p: No captain, you shall be as master, to command, and I will be your servant to obey.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: You shall command me, madam.

div.head: Scene 34.

sp.p: O! how my soul is tormented with love, shame, grief and fear (She stops a little) I am in love, but am ashamed to make it known, besides, I have given the world cause to censure me, not only in concealing of my sex, and changing of my habit, but being always in the company of men, acting a masculine part upon the world's great stage, and to the public view; but could I live thus concealed, I should be happy, and free from censure: but oh cursed fortune! that pleasure takes in crossing lovers, and basic time that makes all things as restless as itself, doth strive for to divulge my acts, when I have no defence, or honest means for to conceal them; for if I do oppose, I shall become a murderer, and bear a guilty conscience to my grave, which may torment my soul, whenas my body is turned to dust.

div.p: But since there is no remedy, I'll weep my sorrows forth, and with the water of my tears, I'll strive to quench the blushing heat, that like quick lightning, flashes in my face.
div.stage: Enter the lord singularity, finding Affectionata weeping.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: My dear Affectionata, what makes thee so melancholy, as to be always weeping?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I must confess, my lord, here of late my eyes have been like Egypt, when it is overflown with Nilus, and all my thoughts like crocodiles.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: What is the cause?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Alas, my lord, causes lies so obscure, they are seldom found.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: But the effects may give us light to judge what causes are.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Effects deceives, and often cozens us, by reason one effect may be produced from many several causes, and several effects proceeds from one cause.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: But thy tears seems as if they were produced from some passion.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Indeed they are produced from passions and appetites, for passions are the rays of the mind, and appetites the vapour of the senses, and the rays of my mind hath drawn up the vapour of my senses into thick moist clouds, which falls in showering tears.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: Tell me thy griefs, and thy desires, that I may help the one, and ease the other.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Alas, my lord, I cannot, for they lie in the conceptions; and conceptions ariseth like mists, and my thoughts like clouds, lies one above another.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: Come, come, let reason the sun of the soul verify those misty conceptions, and disperse this dull humour, that the mind may be clear, and the thoughts serene.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I will strive to bring in the light of mirth.

div.head: Scene 35.
div.stage: Enter the lady Wagtail, the lady amorous, and sir Humphry bold.

sp.speaker: Lady wagtail.
sp.p: Good sir Humphrey bold, carry us to the court of judicatures, to hear the great trial, which is said to be today.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry bold.
sp.p: You would go to hear the condemnation of an old man, and his old wife.

sp.speaker: Lady wagtail.
sp.p: No, we would go to hear the confessions, as whether they have murdered the young lady that is missing, or not.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry bold.
sp.p: Why, that you may hear from other relations, as well as from their own mouths, and so save you so much pains and trouble, as you will have to get a place, and to stand so long a time, as the examining, accusing, confessing, freeing, or condemning, which will require so long a time, as ladies will find great inconveniences, and be put mightily to it.

sp.speaker: Lady wagtail.
sp.p: But I long to hear and see the manner of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry bold.
sp.p: I will wait upon you, but you will be very much crowded.

sp.speaker: Lady amorous.
sp.p: I had rather see them hanged, if they be guilty, than hear them judged and condemned.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry bold.
sp.p: Why, a condemning judge is the chief hangman, for he hangs with his word, as the other with a cord.

sp.speaker: Lady wagtail.
sp.p: Will the lord singularity be there?

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry bold.
sp.p: Yes certainly, for he is the man that doth accuse them.

sp.speaker: Lady amorous.
sp.p: And will his son be there?

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry bold.
sp.p: I know not that.

div.head: Scene 36.
div.stage: Enter the judges and jurymen, as in a court of judicature; the lord singularity, Foster Trusty, and nurse Fondly, and many others to hear them.

sp.speaker: Judges.
sp.p: Who accuses these persons of murder?

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: Ay, my lord.

sp.speaker: Foster trusty.
sp.p: We beseech your honours, not to condemn us before you have found us guilty.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: It is a proof sufficient, my lord, they cannot clear themselves, or produce the party that was delivered to their trust and care.

sp.speaker: Judges.
sp.p: Jury, do you find them guilty or not?

sp.speaker: Juries.
sp.p: Guilty, my lord.

sp.speaker: Judges.
sp.p: Then from the jury, we can —.

div.stage: Enter Affectionata, dressed very fine in her own sex's habit, and stops the judge's sentence.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Hold, condemn not these innocent persons for their fidelity, constancy and love; I am that maid they are accused to murder, and by good circumstances can prove it.

div.stage: All the assembly, judges and jury, seems as in a maze at her beauty, and stares on her. The lord singularity, as soon as he seeth her, starts back, then goeth towards her, his eyes all the time sixth on her; speaking as to himself.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: Sure it is that face.

div.stage: He takes her by the hand, and turns her to the light; are not you my Affectionata, whom I adopted my son.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Shame stops my breath, and chokes the words I should utter.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: For heaven's sake speak quickly, release my fears, or crown my joys.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: My lord, pray pardon loves follies, and condemn not my modesty for dissembling my sex; for my designs were harmless, as only to follow you as a servant: for by heaven, my lord? my only desire was, that my eyes, and my ears might be fed with the sight of your person, and sound of your voice, which made me travel to hear, and to see you: but since I am discovered, I will otherwise conceal myself, and live as an anchoret from the view of the world.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: Pray let me live with you.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: That may not be, for an anchoret is to live alone.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: If you will accept of me for your husband, we shall be as one.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: You have declared against marriage, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: I am converted, and shall become so pious a devote, as I shall offer at no altar but Hymen's, and since I am your convert, refuse me not.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I love too well to refuse you.

div.stage: He kneels down on one knee, and kisses her hand.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: Here on my knee I do receive you as a blessing, and a gift from the gods.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Most reverend judges, and grave jury, sentence me not with censure, nor condemn me to scandals, for waiting as a man, and serving as a page; for though I dissembled in my outward habit and behaviour, yet I was always chaste and modest in my nature.

div.head: Scene 37.
div.stage: Enter the lady Wagtail, and lady amorous.

sp.speaker: Lady wagtail.
sp.p: Now lady amorous, is your mind a myrtle-grove, and your thoughts nightingales to entertain the idea of your Adonis.

sp.speaker: Lady amorous.
sp.p: Her discovery hath proved the boar that killed him; but I desire much to be army Adonis funeral, which is the lady Orphant's wedding.

sp.speaker: Lady wagtail.
sp.p: I am acquainted with some of the lord Singularity's captains and officers, and I will speak to some of them to speak to the lord singularity to invite us.

sp.speaker: Lady amorous.
sp.p: I pray do, for since my Adonis is dead, I will strive to enamour Mars, which is the lord singularity himself.

sp.speaker: Lady wagtail.
sp.p: Faith, that is unfriendly done, for I have laid my designs for himself.

sp.speaker: Lady amorous.
sp.p: I fear both of our designs may come to nothing, he is so enamoured with his own she-page, or female son.

div.head: Scene 38.
div.stage: Enter nurse Fondly, and Foster Trusty.

sp.speaker: Nurse fondly.
sp.p: O husband! This is the joyfullest day that ever I had in my whole life, except at mine own wedding.

sp.speaker: Foster trusty.
sp.p: Indeed, this day is a day of jubilee.

sp.speaker: Nurse fondly.
sp.p: Of Juno, say you; but husband, have you provided good cheer, and enough; for here are a world of guests come, more than was invited, and you being master steward, will be thought too blame, if there be any thing wanting.

sp.speaker: Foster trusty.
sp.p: If you be as careful to dress the bride's chamber, as I to provide for the bridal guest, you nor I shall be in a fault.

sp.speaker: Nurse fondly.
sp.p: I saith, if you have done your part, as I have done my part, we shall deserve praise.

sp.speaker: Foster trusty.
sp.p: I saith, we are almost so old, that we are almost past praise.

sp.speaker: Nurse fondly.
sp.p: None can merit praise, but those in years; for all worthy, noble and heroic acts requires time to do them, and who was ever wise, that was young?

sp.speaker: Foster trusty.
sp.p: And few are praised that are old, for as fame divulgeth merits, so time wears out praise, for time hath more power than fame, striving to destroy what fame desires to keep. The truth is, time is a glutton, for he doth not only strive to destroy what fame divulgeth, but what himself begets and produceth.

div.head: Scene 39.
div.stage: Enter the lord singularity, and the lady orphan, as bride and bridegroom, and a company of bridal-guests.

sp.speaker: Musitioners.
sp.p: We desire your excellence will give us leave to present you with a song written by my lord marquess of Newcastle.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: Your present could have never been less acceptable, by reason it will retard my marriage.

sp.speaker: Lady orphan.
sp.p: Pray, my lord, hear them.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: Come, come, dispatch, dispatch.
sp.stage: He seems not to listen to them. All the time his eyes fixed on the bride.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Then love it was thy fate

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: By heaven, musicianers, you are all so dilatory with your damnable and harsh prologue of tuning before you play, as the next parliament will make it felony in fiddlers, if not treason, when your great royal ears; begin with a F●● to you.

sp.speaker: Musicians.
sp.p: Why, my noble lord, we have done.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: By heaven, there spoke Apollo! Give them ten pieces.

sp.speaker: Musicians.
sp.p: Madam, an Eppilanian! we have more to express our further joy, and then we will pray for blessings on you both.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: O! it will be my funeral song, you rogues, know all delays doth kill me; and at this time your best music sounds harsh, and out of tune.

sp.speaker: Lady orphan.
sp.p: Pray let them sing that one song more; so ends your trouble of them.

sp.speaker: Lord singularity.
sp.p: Begin, quick, quick.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: O love, some says thou art a boy!
But now turned girl, thy master's joy.
Now cease all thy fierce alarms,
In circles of your loving arms.
Who can express the joys tonight ,
Nay, all those pleasures you'll control,
With joining your each soul to soul.
Thus in love's raptures live, till you
And than your airy journey take,

div.stage: The song done, the music plays, as the bride and bridegroom goeth.
